	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Death of the GUI</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/death-of-the-gui/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Dec 2016 17:46:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2444</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<style>
	p a {
		color:rgba(239, 109, 34, 0.7) !important;
		position: relative !important;
	}
	p a:hover {
		color:rgba(239, 109, 34, 1) !important;
	}
</style>

<p>The messaging revolution for the US consumer began when <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2007/07/02/deal-is-confirmed-google-acquired-grandcentral/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">Google purchased Grand Central, which became Google Voice in 2007</a>. Starting in 2011, a flood of messaging-like apps were launched, and consolidation of the players began, with <a href="http://news.microsoft.com/2011/05/10/microsoft-to-acquire-skype/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">Microsoft buying Skype</a> and then Apple released iMessage in 2012. The iMessage release had significant importance: for the first time iMessage gave consumers access to their messages and SMS across all Apple devices - their iPhones, iPads and MacBooks. Eventually Facebook entered the fray by <a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-10-28/facebook-s-22-billion-whatsapp-deal-buys-10-million-in-sales" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">buying WhatsApp</a> for a whopping $22BN in 2014, along with the release on all major platforms.</p>

<p>All these apps have two things in common: <strong>messages </strong>and <strong>ubiquity… </strong>access to messages / phone calls anywhere and at any time. In the next evolution of these messaging services, AI Bots are being released for all these messaging platforms, with Facebook leading the charge with much fanfare surrounding wit.ai-based bots for Facebook messenger.   Google and Microsoft have facilitated the development of AI-base bots, with their respective publishing of api.ai and the Microsoft bot framework for developers. WeChat, Line, Facebook, Skype, Slack and Telegram are messaging platforms that already enable interaction with third-party services from within the messaging interface using bots, with Facebook’s Whatsapp and Google’s Allo rumored to join in soon.</p>

<p>To quote this <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2015/09/29/forget-apps-now-the-bots-take-over/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">article</a> in TechCrunch
<blockquote><em>Messaging bots can read and write messages just like a human would. Bots can be programmed to carry out automated actions. Bots can both initiate action as well as respond to requests from other users. Bots are of different kinds, too; they automate conversations, transactions or workflows.</em></blockquote>
When you look at the world’s mostly widely used messaging platform, WeChat, and look at some of its more innovative features, you realize that it offers users the ability to have a storefront on their platform and to buy goods and services using chat messages. More importantly, it does away with the notion of a GUI as the model to interact with a retailer or service provider.</p>

A quick example might make the point. You go to the Post Office to buy postage stamps to ship a parcel. Here's what you would do naturally. You would walk up to the counter and say - “ <em>I'm shipping a package that weighs 1 pound to New York to zip code 10019 via parcel post</em>” . The counter clerk may clarify the requirements by saying - “<em>Do you want to take advantage of the “Flat Rate” boxes”</em> to which you might inquire about the cost and then make a quick decision to send it “Flat Rate” or “Parcel Post” based on price and speed.</p>

Now imagine if the human were to act like a GUI. So you would walk up to the counter clerk and say:</p>

<ul style="text-indent: 2em;">
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> I want to buy postage?</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk: <em>What kind of postage?</em></li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> To ship a 1 lb box</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk:<em> Flat Rate,Parcel Post, …</em> (equivalent to a drop-down list)</li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> What are the rates?</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk: <em>What zip code?</em></li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> 10019</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk: <em>How fast?</em></li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> 2 days</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk: <em>$18.75 for Flat Rate - 2 days priority</em></li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> What about 5 days?</em></li>
 	<li>Counter Clerk: <em>That would be Ground and would be for a max of 5 days for delivery and $11 total</em></li>
 	<li><strong>You:</strong><em> I will buy $11 option</em></li>
</ul>
<div class="col-xs-12"><p>One can clearly see the difference between a conversational model and a hierarchical GUI model; the conversational model is much more natural. In China small businesses have stopped creating websites, <a href="http://digiday.com/brands/wechat-mobile-commerce/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">but instead have a presence on the WeChat platform to sell and support their wares</a>. User Interfaces as we know them are going to change forever. In fact Facebook messenger has announced that now you can call Uber and Lyft directly from their chat client (see below),</p></div>
<div class="col-sm-4 col-sm-offset-4" style="padding:30pt 0px"><img class="img-responsive" src="https://media.licdn.com/mpr/mpr/AAEAAQAAAAAAAAkGAAAAJGRlZTllZGNlLWU5ZmYtNGVmZS04MmRmLTA2YTllY2Q5ZDU4ZA.png" /></div><div class="col-sm-3"> </div>
<div class="col-sm-12"><p>and in countries like India and Brazil, Uber and local cab companies like Ola cabs and 99Taxis are integrated directly into Google maps.</p>

<p>Interestingly, an unintended consequence of this shift is that we don’t have to - and indeed, cannot - pre-determine the paths and choices that consumers have to take in our apps and on our websites. Instead we have to constantly train our AI engines every time we encounter new scenarios. Fortunately this Bot model allows us to <em>hand over the conversation to humans</em> if the conversation with the consumer runs into a “wall” and is not decipherable!</p></div>
<div class="col-sm-4 col-sm-offset-4" style="padding:30pt 0px"><img class="img-responsive" src="https://media.licdn.com/mpr/mpr/AAEAAQAAAAAAAAfcAAAAJGQ4NjU1MjZkLWJjZTMtNDY4My1iYzE0LWE1M2I3NTQ3NjIzMw.jpg" /></div>
<div class="col-xs-12"><p>This warm hand-off to a human makes this model very flexible. This also compresses code dev time as the GUI design exercise is replaced by Q&amp;A design. GUI apps inherently tend to be limited by our knowledge of a domain, and even though we may have spent hours poring over GUI mockups and comps, we inevitably miss a branch or a use case, requiring us to constantly deploy hot-fixes for scenarios that we had not modeled. Note that this opens up the challenge to design powerful Q&amp;A mockup tools, but we will talk about that in a later post :).</p></div>
<br>
<div class="col-xs-12"><p>As Siri’s, Cortana’s and Google Now’s Voice-to-Text become more accurate, and as the embedded processors become even faster, I clearly see a day when we will all wear watches like Tom Cruise in Minority Report - Voila: <em>No GUIs ... just conversations</em>!!</p></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[The Death of the GUI]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2444</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-12-08 09:46:14]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-12-08 17:46:14]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[death-of-the-gui]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-news"><![CDATA[Industry News]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Texting is not equal to Communication</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/texting-%e2%89%a0-communications/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 11 Dec 2016 22:28:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2485</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">The famous </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Albert Mehrabian</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">developed a communication model in which he demonstrated that only 7% of what we communicate consists of the literal content of the message. The use of one’s voice, such as tone, intonation, and volume, makes up 38% of the message and as much as 55% of communication consists of non-verbal factors such as body language.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m sure you can think of a phrase that could mean totally different things should the emphasis be placed differently. That’s why great salespeople excel when the customer is in front of them. They know to mimic customer behavior and use these non-verbal communicators to their advantage and to emphasize and sell. And it works.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Today we live in a new society filled with digital communications – emails, chat, and text, to name a few. The problem is that the more non-verbal communication you utilize, the less effective the communication becomes. Yet we continue to try to communicate with our customers via solutions that, while they may be convenient, are less effective and can lead to misunderstandings.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A big trend currently favored in the automotive industry is texting. While it is very effective for short messages that need quick answers, salespeople who rely on texting to sell cars will find it difficult, or almost impossible, to accomplish what could be done with the customer in front of them or on the phone. And this includes service advisors delivering service recommendations. Yes, I am a huge supporter of texting to improve communications with customers under some circumstances – it is a great way to get hold of the customer and send them a link to the recommendations so you are not playing constant phone tag. But if it is a repair that needs explaining, I can guarantee that the customer is going to have questions and will want to discuss it on the phone.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">So let us examine a quick interaction for a service repair, one attempted solely with text and another with a combination of text and voice calls.</span>

<b>Advisor - Text</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">: “</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our technician has found some issues with your car, I am sending you an estimate below:</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">1. Battery failed battery test - Replace Battery - $299.50</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">2. Remove air cleaner and coil packs replace spark plugs - $214.25</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">That would be $513.75 in addition to your A service which would be a total of $889.92”</span></i>

<b>Customer - Text</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">: </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">“Whoa, hold on there?  Why so much?  What is a coil pack? My car was working when I got there, why a new battery?</span></i>

<b>VERSUS</b>
<p style="text-align: left;"><b>
<img class="size-medium wp-image-2497 alignleft" src="https://mykaarma.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/641C4F79-4411-49C9-AEAE-CA8C4235EB7D-291x300.png" alt="" width="291" height="300" />Advisor - Text:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> “</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our technician has found some issues with your car, when might I call you</span></i></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><b>Customer calls </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">- </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Service Advisor talks to the customer and explains that they put the car through multiple tests and the battery test had failed and if the battery was not replaced, then the car might stall on the freeway or may not start in the parking lot, also explains why the spark plugs need replacement etc. Lets the customer know that he will summarize this and send it back to the customer along with the discount that they agreed on.</span></i></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><b>Advisor Text</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">: </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">I am sending you the prices as we agreed:</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">1. Battery failed battery test - Replace Battery - $299.50</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">2. Remove air cleaner and coil packs replace spark plugs - $214.25</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">That would be $513.75 in addition to your A service which would be a total of $889.92.  Your discount is $89.92 and we will be doing this for $800 even”</span></i></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><b>Customer Text: </b><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sure go ahead</span></i></p>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">While the interaction above is representative of an example that I found in our communications database, the numbers have been altered to protect any proprietary information.  The combination of multiple channels of communications is extremely effective, especially when you have to justify an expense that the customer was not expecting.  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I am a huge advocate of texting and other modern methods of communication to help better service the customer and keep them in the loop on such things as the progress of their vehicle during service, changing appointment times, etc. However, it is not the be all and end all of communication.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Tech giant Apple recognized this problem when it rolled out audio text capabilities. Emojis have become modern versions of hieroglyphics in an attempt to add expressiveness, emphasis, and interpretation to text messages. But they aren’t perfect and an emoji certainly wouldn’t stand up in court as issuing consent, understanding or agreement.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When considering how best to communicate, it is important to factor in which channel is most appropriate and will be the most effective. Every channel of communication has certain advantages but some are simply more effective and reliable than others depending upon the reason for communicating. The magic phrase in my mind is:</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><em><strong><span style="color: #ff0000;">When might I call you?</span></strong></em>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Take a look at how you are communicating with your customers and be sure to choose the right channel for the right circumstance. This increases the probability that your customers will interact with you with full comprehension and without misinterpretation. And that means happy and loyal customers, improved CSI and increased Gross Profits.
</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Texting is not equal to Communication]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Puttin’ On the Ritz</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/puttin-on-the-ritz/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Dec 2016 21:38:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2516</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">I was on a trip to New York and met up with a friend of mine (full disclosure: also a happy customer) Richard Hesse, the Dealer Principal at Mercedes-Benz of Nanuet (New York). He has a simple mantra: “It's not business, it’s personal” -- and he means it.  I borrowed a car from him while I was in the NY area and had a minor issue come up with the toll pass at the booth.  I called the store and his receptionist picked up.  She was very courteous, heard me out, and said she would call me back.  Amazingly, she called me back and, to my surprise, solved the problem right away.  She had to find the loaner supervisor, get the answer for me, and return to her desk so she could call me back.  This lady manifested Rich’s mantra -- “It's not business, it’s personal.”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Dealerships are constantly looking for ways to differentiate themselves, attract new customers, and retain the ones they have. Some dealerships even spend millions of dollars installing luxury amenities such as movie theaters, coffee bars, and beauty salons in an effort to create a great customer experience and, thereby, engender customer loyalty. But are such things necessary?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The problem is that no amenity or luxury will make the customer experience great if the fundamentals of good service don’t come first. Customer expectations are simple: (1) The dealership should have a welcoming environment and be clean; (2)The staff should be attentive and responsive to the customer, and (3) the car needs to be fixed right the first time.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The service must be prompt and address the customer’s precise needs and wants. In essence, your dealership should satisfy the need that brought the customer to the dealership while providing a welcoming environment that makes the customer want to return. These are the fundamentals of good service that will make your customer willing to travel to your dealership. Every other luxury or amenity you may choose to provide is the icing on the cake.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Make each experience great and the customer will come back. They may even recommend you to a friend or two.</span>

[wpdevart_poll id="6" theme="1"]

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[“It's not business, it’s personal.”]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="font-size-13px"><![CDATA[font-size 13px]]></category>

		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="font-weight-bold"><![CDATA[font-weight bold]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="fundamentals-of-good-service"><![CDATA[fundamentals of good service]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="height-23px"><![CDATA[height 23px]]></category>

		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="not-business-its-personal"><![CDATA[not business it's personal]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="online-bill-pay"><![CDATA[online bill pay]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="opinions"><![CDATA[Opinions]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[software]]></category>

		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2521]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wpas_done_all]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Don’t get distracted by the Shiny Objects</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/dont-get-distracted-shiny-objects/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jan 2017 16:20:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2629</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When looking at the future of the auto industry, specifically retail, it’s easy to get caught up in the “shiny objects” and focus on all the cool technology such as autonomous cars, ride-sharing, virtual reality sales, and all of the “disruptors” that are entering the space.

<span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">This can serve as a bit of a distraction and, as a result, many tend to stop thinking about the single most important thing in all of this: The Customer. Yes, some would argue that so-called disruptors are focusing on the customer – and these new technologies are certainly attempting to identify customer pain points.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">But let’s stop for a minute and think about the commonality that exists in every disruptor -- they work hard to provide convenience, better customer interaction and engagement.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">The future of the retail auto industry lies in the transformation of the customer experience in both sales and service. When interacting with your dealership, customers simply want the process to be easy, take less time and be more convenient for them, </span><b>not for you</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dealerships who learn this and adapt quickly will find that customers interact with them more often – and you certainly can’t sell or service a vehicle without interaction. It is vital to enable transactions through a channel of your customer’s choice. And those channels change dynamically depending on the reason for the interaction. For example, when scheduling service many customers just want to call in and make their appointment and get an email confirmation. When getting their vehicle serviced they would like text updates about vehicle status and want to receive their recommendation via email, so they can quickly review and approve. If it is a big repair, they probably want to call and talk to someone to get clarification.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">There will always be tire-kickers, those who like to negotiate for hours at a dealership and even those who want a 100% online car-buying process. Each of those customers simply wants to interact in different ways and have it be their choice … not one you force on them. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">When a customer wants to interact with you through a specific channel but you don’t offer it, what happens then? They will deal with you this one time, but will probably pick some other store that is “friendlier” the next time. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Due to the speed of technology development, our industry is in a transformative state. However, there will always be a need for interaction at some level. So don’t get lost in all the “shiny objects” as really it all boils down to is one thing: Customer interactions that promote convenience. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">

</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Don’t get distracted by the Shiny Objects]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2629</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="auto-industry"><![CDATA[auto industry]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="automotive"><![CDATA[automotive]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="automotive-service"><![CDATA[automotive service]]></category>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2631]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_jetpack_dont_email_post_to_subs]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Give Service Advisors a Break – It’s Time to Reduce the Noise</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/give-service-advisors-break-time-reduce-noise/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Jan 2017 07:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2678</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Many dealers and managers outside of the service department don’t realize how incredibly busy a service advisor (SA) is throughout their day. Keep in mind that these are front-line employees dealing directly with your customers. They have an extremely important role in the dealership. In fact, it could be argued that a SA has more influence on a dealership’s livelihood when it comes to customer retention and loyalty than any other position in the dealership. A single SA sees many more customers in a day than any salesperson.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Don’t believe me about how busy these guys and gals are? Try calling a SA between 4 and 6 pm (their peak time for delivery of cars) for assistance. You will likely go straight to voicemail. If you do reach them they’ll tell you they’ll call you right back – and you will have to wait a while for that return call. This is happening more often than most dealers realize. As a mystery shopping exercise, I would recommend that the GMs or Principals of the dealership call their own main 800# between 4 and 6 pm act like you are a customer and are trying to get hold of your SA and see how hard it is.  Start a stopwatch and do the exercise 10 times and if you get connected to your SA directly count  it is a success.  When we analyzed recordings of the main number, here are some statistics that surprised us.  It took an average of 3 minutes to get to a human or voicemail and the customer got the correct SA only 1 out of 10 times. Now put on the “shoes of the customer” who sees you once every 8-10 months, is this what you want happening?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I believe this has a lot to do with the general trend of automation. As OEMs push more and more responsibilities off onto the dealer, the service advisor has become overloaded and it’s time to reduce the noise.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I actually counted the # of tasks that a SA is responsible for at the dealership and I stopped counting at  15 ….:</span>
<ol style="text-indent: 50px;">
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">1)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Greeting customers upon arrival.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">2)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Performing a visual inspection of the vehicle for dings/dents upon intake.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">3)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Consulting with the customer about vehicle ailments and creating a repair order.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">4)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dispatching the work to technicians.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">5)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Contacting the customer with the diagnosis and/or any additional service recommendations and maintaining contact regarding        vehicle status.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">6)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Checking with the parts department for parts availability on the repair order.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">7)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Checking for any open recalls and/or TSBs for each vehicle.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">8)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Checking to see if vehicle is in warranty.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">9)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Looking at the vehicle’s history for any prior repairs that may affect the current problem.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">10)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Greeting tow truck drivers and liaising with shuttle drivers.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">11)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Handling calls and answering questions from customers and others with general questions about vehicle service.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">12)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Submitting factory and extended warranty claims.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">13)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Arranging for pickup and delivery of customers and/or vehicles.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">14)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Coordinating with the loaner desk to make sure loaners are available.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">15)  </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Staying up to date/certified on any OEM software and OEM certifications.</span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">And this list doesn’t include all the additional internal forms they need to fill out and the training they need to complete to remain compliant with regulatory rules. It’s exhausting and its day in and day out.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The customer tends to get lost in all this noise. It’s similar to the medical profession today as things get more and more automated and digitized. There used to be an art to diagnosing and dealing with the patient. My uncle is a doctor and back in the day, you would get a full physical exam which included tapping different parts of your body, listening on the stethoscope for clues to illnesses. Today your Doctor will wheel in a computer and spend the bulk of his time entering data into a computer.  The modern doctors have become dignified digital clerks!!  Do you want this to happen to your SAs?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">This art of personalization has been lost in vehicle service too. If you would like your service department to be effective and provide a great customer experience, find a way to reduce the noise in your service advisors’ daily lives. Take some time to truly study the service department and I am sure you can find some ways to help increase efficiency so there is less noise and forms for the service advisors to fill out. This will then help increase customer interactions and provide a better customer experience which leads to increased CSI and profitability. And then everyone wins.</span>

[wpdevart_poll id="7" theme="1"]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Give Service Advisors a Break....]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="arialhelvetica-neuehelveticasans-serif"><![CDATA[arial,helvetica neue,helvetica,sans-serif]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="automotive"><![CDATA[automotive]]></category>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="car-service"><![CDATA[car service]]></category>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="communication"><![CDATA[communication]]></category>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="conversational-commerce"><![CDATA[conversational commerce]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Customer Interaction App Enables Lexus of Jacksonville to Keep Service Department Running During Massive Power Outage</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/customer-interaction-app-enables-lexus-jacksonville-keep-service-department-running-massive-power-outage/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Jan 2017 17:29:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2696</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="contentsContainer">
<div id="contents">
<p id="E8"><strong><span id="E9" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Customer Interaction App Enables Lexus of Jacksonville to </span><span id="E11" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Keep Service Department Running During Massive Power Outage</span></strong></p>
<p id="E13"><span id="E14" class="qowt-font3-Arial">LONG BEACH, Calif.,-- January 9</span><span id="E17" class="qowt-font3-Arial">, 2017 --</span><span id="E18" class="qowt-font3-Arial">  myKaarma, t</span><span id="E25" class="qowt-font3-Arial">he cloud-based conversational commerce s</span><span id="E29" class="qowt-font3-Arial">oftware that’s revolutionizing the auto service industry, today announced that Lexus of Jacksonville has been able to keep its service department up and running despite losing power and phones by maintaining two-way interaction with customers and allowing them to view and pay for service recommendations via the </span><span id="E31" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E33" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> platform.</span></p>
<p id="E35"><span id="E36" class="qowt-font3-Arial">According to Khai Ferguson, service manager at Lexus of Jacksonville, a direct lightning strike close to the building caused the dealership to lose power for several hours. The computers had battery backup for a couple of hours but there was no power. The phone system was tied into the power so it was down, the dealership only had partial Internet use and no access to customer files. The phones were not fully operational for two whole days, but this did not affect operations in the service department.</span></p>
<p id="E38"><span id="E39" class="qowt-font3-Arial">“We would have had to shut things down were it not for </span><span id="E41" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E43" class="qowt-font3-Arial">. It’s a lifesaver. We had another lightning strike and power outage today and it enabled us to text updates and service recommendations to our customers, get approvals and even have them pay through the platform. I had one elderly customer who really needed her vehicle done. She had called in, was unable to reach us and was very concerned. I was able to reach her via text, send recommendations and she was able to review and pay for them online through the </span><span id="E45" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E47" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> app,” Ferguson said.</span></p>
<p id="E49"><span id="E50" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Approximately two years ago Lexus of Jacksonville was using email and phone calls to reach their service customers with updates and to get approval for recommendations. Service advisors were frustrated by the amount of time it took to get recommendations approved and customer calls tended to go straight to voicemail, leaving the customer less than satisfied with the service experience. The dealership was looking for a way to improve customer interaction and came across </span><span id="E52" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E54" class="qowt-font3-Arial">.</span></p>
<p id="E56"><span id="E57" class="qowt-font3-Arial">“Email and voicemail are nowhere near as effective as text. Customers are bombarded with emails and they tend to go straight to spam. Now a text message pops up and the customer can quickly respond. Even elderly people use text these days as their grandkids tend to teach them. Our authorization time has reduced from something like two hours to a matter of minutes. That is a huge time saving and increase in productivity for our dealership. Our customers love it, as do our service advisors. If I tried to take this away from them I think there would literally be a riot,” Ferguson commented.</span></p>
<p id="E59"><span id="E60" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Lexus of Jacksonville has 25 service bays, 23 techs, 8 service advisors and writes approximately 80 ROs per day. With </span><span id="E62" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma,</span><span id="E64" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> the service advisors can text or call the customer from their smartphones or tablets with one recognizable service department number, or email the customer through the platform via their desktop computer. All communication is logged within the platform for future reference.</span></p>
<p id="E66"><span id="E67" class="qowt-font3-Arial">When a service advisor is on break and the customer needs to get in contact, “follow-me” technology sends the message to the service advisor’s smartphone, allowing them to reply even when not at their desk, while capturing the message in the cloud. Or the service advisor can delegate the message to another service advisor to handle. Instead of struggling to connect through phone tag, the advisor can update and get authorization from the customer in minutes.</span></p>
<p id="E68"><span id="E69" class="qowt-font3-Arial">When the customer’s vehicle is done a payment request is sent to that customer through the </span>app with a cash repair invoice, allowing the customer to verify repairs and pay on their smartphone tablet, or PC, without logging into a website.</p>

</div>
</div>
<div id="contentsContainer">
<div id="contents">
<p id="E72"><span id="E73" class="qowt-font3-Arial">“A good forty percent of our customers now pay online directly through the app,” Ferguson said. “This truly is technology in action -- imagine how much time that saves, how much more productive our personnel can be, and how much more satisfied our customers are as a result.”</span></p>
<p id="E75"><span id="E76" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Ferguson also likes the accountability that the platform provides. </span><span id="E77" class="qowt-font3-Arial">All calls are recorded and searchable so that the service manager can review and help any advisor that has a problem or a dispute with a customer over recommendations. The service manager can also check in on any text interactions between advisors and customers to ensure that everything is going smoothly.</span></p>
<p id="E79"><span id="E80" class="qowt-font3-Arial">“Our authorization disputes have reduced by more than fifty percent, productivity has improved by more than fifty percent and we have seen a substantial increase in our CSI as a result of this technology. It truly has enhanced the retail experience for our service customers,” Ferguson stated.</span></p>
<p id="E82"><span id="E83" class="qowt-font3-Arial">For more information, or to schedule a product demonstration, stop by booth # 5501 at NADA 100 in New Orleans, LA, Jan 27-29, 2017, or visit mykaarma.com.</span></p>
<p id="E89"><span id="E90" class="qowt-font3-Arial"># # # # #</span></p>
<p id="E92"><a id="E93" contenteditable="false" href="https://mykaarma.com/our-company/" target="_blank"><span id="E94" class="qowt-font3-Arial">About </span><span id="E96" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E98" class="qowt-font3-Arial">:</span></a></p>
<p id="E99"><span id="E102" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E105" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> is a conversational commerce software company for automotive dealerships that focuses on enhancing the retail service department experience. </span><span id="E108" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma's</span><span id="E111" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> platform gives dealers the ability to offer their customers 21st Century technology through digital conversations and smart payment systems. </span></p>
<p id="E113"><span id="E116" class="qowt-font3-Arial">myKaarma</span><span id="E119" class="qowt-font3-Arial"> Media Contact:</span></p>
<p id="E120"><span id="E121" class="qowt-font3-Arial">Thomas Ross </span></p>
<p id="E122"><span id="E123" class="qowt-font3-Arial">tom.ross@mykaarma.com</span></p>
<p id="E124"><span id="E125" class="qowt-font3-Arial">562.349.1356 </span></p>

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>myKaarma Launches Remote Repair &amp; Drop Off Service for Auto Dealer Service Departments</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/mykaarma-launches-remote-repair-drop-off-service-auto-dealer-service-departments/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Jan 2017 06:51:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2720</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b>LONG BEACH, Calif.,-- January 16, 2017</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> -- </span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">myKaarma,</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> the cloud-based</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">conversational commerce</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> software that’s revolutionizing the auto service industry, today announced the launch of their new Remote Repair &amp; Drop Off Service that helps auto dealers better manage shuttle drivers and the customer pick up/drop off process, leading to increased customer satisfaction and retention. The new module takes customer service to the next level, providing an Uber-like experience.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">According to myKaarma CEO Ujj Nath, at most dealerships, drivers are currently managed by a spreadsheet or just a piece of paper where customers sign up to be dropped off at a location ad hoc. “This creates unnecessary anxiety for customers who do not know when the driver is coming back, or when they will arrive at their location to pick them up,” said Nath. “Dealerships are also unable to easily communicate the locations of the pickups and drop offs to their drivers. They have to perhaps call and read off addresses, which creates a lot of inefficiencies. Another problem is last minute cancellations. At some dealerships, the shuttle schedule is planned the night before based on appointments received that day. However, the next day a customer might cancel and the driver gets no notification, so still goes to pick them up, which is highly inefficient. Now the entire process can be managed through the myKaarma platform and app so these problems disappear.” Nath added.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">myKaarma’s new Remote Repair &amp; Drop Off Service offers customers a fast and efficient experience. When the dealership driver is assigned, the customer gets a text message, can click on a link to track the driver, get a video of the inspection of their car, view their loaner vehicle, get status updates on their vehicle repair through the myKaarma app, and get a payment request with the invoice they can pay remotely. The customer can then coordinate a pickup time via text with their service advisor.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Upon completion of service, the customer receives a text message allowing them to review the invoice and then pay for it and when the dealership’s driver is on the way with their vehicle, the customer receives a text notification with an ETA and can track their progress. myKaarma provides the customer and the dealership with an electronic record of everything; phone calls, emails, texts, video inspections, etc., which builds and enhances trust between the customer and the dealership.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The new Remote Repair &amp; Drop Off Service allows auto dealerships to efficiently manage the following processes:</span>
<ul>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• Drop off of customers at any location near the dealership after the customer has delivered a vehicle for service.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• Pick up the customer from a location other than the dealership once vehicle service is completed.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• Miscellaneous pickups and drop offs of parts and other items to third parties near the dealership location.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• Pickup and delivery service for remote repair and maintenance. This includes the delivery of a loaner car, pick up of the customer’s car, delivery of the customer’s vehicle after repair and pick up of the loaner car. </span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• All transactions, including a video walk-around inspection by the driver for any pre-existing damage, are recorded and stored online for seven years, with complete traceability.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">• Shuttle drivers can aggregate and route multiple customers to their drop-off/pickup points using routing and tracking software</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">“Today the vehicle drop off and pick up process at dealerships is very archaic.  Customers want speed and transparency. If the customer needs a shuttle there are typically multiple phone calls as the customer waits impatiently with no idea when a driver will arrive to pick them up. When the driver shows up there are a lot of forms and a quick walk around of the customer’s vehicle, but there is no record. The dealer takes a risk that the customer may later state that there was damage and it is their word against the customers,” said Nath. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">“When the vehicle is done, most dealerships call and relay the amount over the phone, get their credit card number (which is not recommended if there is a dispute, you lose the chargeback), create a receipt, show up at the customer’s house, do a switch, get the customer to sign the receipt for the credit card and the repair order. This does not work very well. myKaarma handles all these pain points and brings the whole process into the 21</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">st</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> century with an Uber-like experience,” Nath added.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For more information, or to schedule a product demonstration, stop by booth # 5501 at NADA 100 in New Orleans, LA, Jan 27-29, 2017, or visi</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">t</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">www.mykaarma.com</span>
<p style="text-align: left;"><b>                                                                                                      # # # # #</b></p>
<b>About myKaarma:</b>

myKaarma is a conversational commerce software company for automotive dealerships that focuses on enhancing the retail service department experience. myKaarma's platform gives dealers the ability to offer their customers 21st Century technology through digital conversations and smart payment systems.

<span style="font-weight: 400;">myKaarma </span>

Media Contact:

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Thomas Ross</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">tom.ross@mykaarma.com</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">562.349.1356</span>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[413]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Your Service Competition isn’t Other Dealers -- It’s Joe across the Street</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/service-competition-isnt-dealers-joe-across-street/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Jan 2017 18:46:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2742</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Customers generally get their vehicle serviced close to home or work. Dealers are lucky that customers feel they should bring their new cars back to the same store when there are warranty issues. They have that warranty period to develop the customer’s loyalty. That is UNLESS their customer has a bad experience. After the warranty period is over if they don’t wish to service at a franchised dealer (often due to the perception that dealers are more expensive) the customer will go to the most convenient independent service repair shop.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">What happens when they go to the independent service repair shop - </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Joe’s Automotive Repair</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Joe answers the phone. There are no voice prompts and no need to get transferred. The customer explains what they need and Joe gives them an estimate. When the customer arrives at Joe’s shop, Joe greets them himself. He then inspects the vehicle and calls them to inform them of any repairs he discovers. After explaining technically what’s going on, he gives them a final amount, gets approval and repairs the vehicle. When the work is completed, Joe notifies the customer that their vehicle is ready. When the customer returns, Joe takes the customer’s payment and explains to the customer the work that was completed. A few days later, Joe calls the customer to find out if everything is to the customer’s complete satisfaction.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are so many moving parts at a franchised dealership, as well as a number of different employees involved in a typical service process. That it is why it is very hard for franchised dealers to compete with the experience offered by independent service centers.  Therefore, ensuring a smooth and excellent customer experience, providing a single point of contact who responds to the customer as well as personalizing the service experience, is quite a challenge.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When attempting to provide a higher level of customer experience many dealers typically resort to hiring more people to help – more porters, greeters, assistants, BDC personnel, etc. The customer now has to deal with a service advisor, greeter, valet, porter and BDC personnel -- The list goes on and it borders on overkill.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Take a look at the experience from your customer’s viewpoint. To compete with Joe’s Garage across the street, focus on improving interaction with your customers by providing a streamlined, efficient, and unified way for customers to interact with you. If the customer has to remember five phone numbers or speak with multiple people at the dealership in order to get their vehicle serviced, eventually they will get tired of it.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Simplify your service process and make it easy for the customer to do business with you -- or you will lose your customer to Joe.</span>

&nbsp;

[wpdevart_poll id="8" theme="1"]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[ Your Service Competition isn’t Other Dealers...]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2742</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2017-01-18 18:46:32]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[service-competition-isnt-dealers-joe-across-street]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>

		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="arial-narrowarialhelvetica-neuehelveticasans-serif"><![CDATA[arial narrow,arial,helvetica neue,helvetica,sans-serif]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="automotive"><![CDATA[automotive]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="automotive-service"><![CDATA[automotive service]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="bdc-personnel"><![CDATA[bdc personnel]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="car-service"><![CDATA[car service]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="color-878787"><![CDATA[color #878787]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="communication"><![CDATA[communication]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="customer"><![CDATA[customer]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="customer-experience"><![CDATA[customer experience]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="customer-interaction"><![CDATA[customer interaction]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="customer-interaction-management"><![CDATA[customer interaction management]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="customer-service"><![CDATA[customer service]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="fixed-ops"><![CDATA[Fixed Ops]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="font-family-arial"><![CDATA[font-family arial]]></category>
		<category domain="yst_prominent_words" nicename="font-family-arial-narrowarialhelvetica"><![CDATA[font-family arial narrow,arial,helvetica]]></category>

	<item>
		<title>Ujj Nath // Effective Communications with Recall Customers</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/ujj-nath-effective-communications-recall-customers/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Feb 2017 14:52:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2772</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ujj Nath // Effective Communications with Recall Customers<h3 style="text-align: center;">myKaarma CEO Ujj Nath discusses the importance of effective communications with recall customers in this short video blog.</h3>
http://kaarya-1.wistia.com/medias/2rxnofnvku?embedType=async&seo=false&videoFoam=true&videoWidth=640]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Ujj Nath // Effective Communications with Recall Customers]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Shuttle Has Left the Building… Maybe</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/shuttle-left-building-maybe/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2017 13:48:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=2999</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<style>
	.poll_main_div_1 .main_div_of_the_poll_answer {
		border-color: transparent !important;
	}
	.poll_question {
		line height: 1.3 !important;
	}
</style>
<p>The Shuttle Has Left the Building… Maybe</p>
<p class="p1">One day, while bringing my vehicle into a large, very well-known dealership for service, a rather comical scene played out before my eyes. While the shuttle driver was leaving the dealership, his mini-van full with customers, all of a sudden a strong gust of wind came through. The shuttle van’s windows were open at the time and papers started flying out of the vehicle. He stopped the vehicle and desperately gave chase to the papers that were flying around. Ironically, these were his printed directions for each passenger. He eventually gave up and went back to the dealership to re-print the directions.</p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">While entertaining, it made me consider the consequences that just one gust of wind had on this dealership’s service department:
</span><span class="s1">
1.</span> <span class="s1">The driver now had to go back to the dealership and reassemble the route</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">2.</span><span class="s2"><span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span></span><span class="s1">The customers in the shuttle had to sit and wait. The shuttle, which was provided as a convenience, was now an inconvenience to them.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">
All because of a piece of paper and a gust of wind.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Why in this era of paperless technology would you choose to use paper-based systems? One of the reasons Uber quickly became so popular is due to its technology and simplicity. Pull out your smartphone, open the app, request a driver and with a couple clicks the app tells you exactly where the driver is and how long you have to wait until pick up. Once the ride is over, you simply get out, and your credit card is automatically charged the fare.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">We all like convenience and technology because it makes doing business easier. Customers frequently make decisions about who they choose to do business with based on the ease of any interaction with that business. You can either choose to adopt new technology or risk being left for a competitive dealership that has.</span></p>
<div class="col-sm-4"
<p class="p1" style="margin-top:30pt;"><span class="s1">[wpdevart_poll id="9" theme="1"]</span></p></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[The Shuttle Has Left the Building… Maybe]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[shuttle-left-building-maybe]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Ujj Nath // Are Your Service Advisors Overloaded?</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/ujj-nath-are-your-service-advisors-overloaded/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Feb 2017 14:52:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[asher.peruscini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=3233</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4 style="text-align: center;">myKaarma CEO, Ujj Nath,explains why dealerships should analyze what their service advisors responsibilities are and asks whether they are overloaded?</h4>
https://mykaarma-3.wistia.com/medias/gc3dfbw8bm]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Stop the Lunacy!</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/stop-the-lunacy/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Mar 2017 22:35:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ujj.nath@mykaarma.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=3241</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Stop the Lunacy!</h1>
For the past 15 years or so, technology has existed which enables customers to schedule service appointments online. In the beginning, the systems were very basic – the customer filled out a form online and an e-mail was sent to someone at the dealership who may – or may not – confirm that appointment.

Fast forward to today and online service appointment scheduling has evolved into systems that immediately verify the service appointment, check parts availability, analyze shop capacity based on other appointments, available bays and technician skill level, among other things.

But guess what? Despite all these advanced abilities, and the convenience to both the customer and the dealer, most dealers’ online appointment scheduling rates hover around 7-10 percent, with the head-of the-pack dealers sitting at around 20 percent – after 15 years a mere 2 out of 10 customers schedule an appointment online!

Today’s customers demand convenience, and, with all this wonderful technology, why are dealers still only getting 2 out of 10 customers to make appointments online—AT MOST?

I’ll tell you why: We went to a dealer’s website, (will remain unnamed, but most of them are the same) and we counted the clicks and inputs for the major scheduler. It took us 9 clicks and 19 inputs to get to an appointment. Is that crazy? I think so!

Yes, everyone wants to “shop load” correctly and plan the capacity. I am not asking you to go away from that, but just asking you to enable a different approach. How about a simple way for the customer to click a button on your website and have the system call them back - a-la Amazon?

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-3243 size-large" src="https://mykaarma.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/amazon_contact-us-1024x854.png" width="640" height="534" />

It is a lot easier to verify the details and look up a recall if the person is calling you.  Now if the customer does not have time to call you, let them text you.

Even that is simpler than the 9-19 step methodology. The fact is that customers don’t make appointments online because we’ve made it too hard to do so.  It reminds me of my doctor today.  When I go in, all she does is type into a computer and keeps collecting data on me, rather than talk to me about my health issues. We should learn from it, we have got to make it easier for customers to interact with us!

Show your customers just how much they can benefit by making an appointment. But first, make it easy for them to do so via your website, text and chat.

In so doing, you can increase your service revenue, traffic, appointments set and customer experience, while utilizing your shop’s resources more efficiently.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Stop the Lunacy!]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3241</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2017-03-02 14:35:03]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2017-03-02 22:35:03]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[stop-the-lunacy]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="opinions"><![CDATA[Opinions]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3242]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_focuskeywords]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_primary_category]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[22]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wpas_done_all]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Ujj Nath - An Unconventional Idea</title>
		<link>https://mykaarma.com/ujj-nath-unconventional-idea/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Mar 2017 15:21:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[asher.peruscini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://mykaarma.com/?p=3365</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<script src="https://fast.wistia.com/embed/medias/3km27qzcvx.jsonp" async></script><script src="https://fast.wistia.com/assets/external/E-v1.js" async></script><div class="wistia_responsive_padding" style="padding:56.25% 0 0 0;position:relative;"><div class="wistia_responsive_wrapper" style="height:100%;left:0;position:absolute;top:0;width:100%;"><div class="wistia_embed wistia_async_3km27qzcvx videoFoam=true" style="height:100%;width:100%">&nbsp;</div></div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Ujj Nath - An Unconventional Idea]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3365</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2017-03-16 08:21:17]]></wp:post_date>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="opinions"><![CDATA[Opinions]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_oembed_2945d8e4677ad4d9966b0a8cc931a487]]></wp:meta_key>
